claims.claim_text: This study tests CNN transfer learning for burial mound detection against 773 field-verified mounds
claims.verbatim_quote: We set out to detect burial mounds in the Kazanlak Valley, Bulgaria, using IKONOS high-resolution satellite imagery

claims.claim_text: External validation against field data is essential for CNN workflows
claims.verbatim_quote: making external validation with field data an essential part of CNN workflows

claims.claim_text: First model (F1=0.87) failed validation: 4.9% detection, 95.3% false negatives
claims.verbatim_quote: Although the first model reported a good fit (F1 = 0.87), validation with field data showed the model was confusing our target features

claims.claim_text: Self-reported ML metrics are misleadingly high compared to actual detection performance
claims.verbatim_quote: self-reported success rates were misleadingly high, and that the model was misidentifying most features

claims.claim_text: Second model (curated training) performed worse than first model (all mounds)
claims.verbatim_quote: Counterintuitively, the model provided with training data selected for highly visible mounds... performed worse

claims.claim_text: Additional training data curation worsened rather than improved performance
claims.verbatim_quote: despite additional curation of the training data, the second run was even less successful than the first

claims.claim_text: Manual approaches would likely be more efficient given 135 hours invested and poor results
claims.verbatim_quote: manual approaches like visual inspection by experts or crowdsourcing to volunteers would probably be more efficient

claims.claim_text: ML-for-archaeology literature exhibits publication bias with overwhelmingly positive reporting
claims.verbatim_quote: The literature itself, however, is overwhelmingly positive, reflecting some combination of publication bias and a rhetoric of unconditional success

claims.claim_text: Complete code transparency achieved via three public repositories
claims.verbatim_quote: scripts are available in public repositories

claims.claim_text: AI/ML approaches nearing mainstream adoption in archaeological remote sensing
claims.verbatim_quote: AI/ML is on the cusp of 'crossing the chasm'

claims.claim_text: This paper provides cautionary counterbalance for ML adopters in archaeology
claims.verbatim_quote: This paper presents the failure of a good-faith attempt to utilise these approaches as a counterbalance and cautionary tale

claims.claim_text: Pre-trained CNNs with low-touch training fail for varied features in heterogeneous landscapes
claims.verbatim_quote: Our attempt to deploy a pre-trained CNN demonstrates the limitations of this approach when it is used to detect varied features... within a heterogeneous landscape

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Field validation is more reliable than self-reported metrics for assessing ML performance
trigger_text: self-reported success rates were misleadingly high
validation with field data showed the model was confusing our target features
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The gap between F1 scores (0.87, 0.62) and actual detection (4.9%, 2.7%) demonstrates that field validation reveals failures hidden by standard metrics.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Transfer learning assumptions may not apply to archaeological applications with heterogeneous targets
trigger_text: Transfer learning assumes that large, complex models can be pre-trained using data from one domain, then fine-tuned for a specific task
even an advanced pre-trained model... is likely to fail when asked to detect somewhat variable features against very heterogeneous backgrounds
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The failure challenges the core assumption that pre-trained models generalise effectively to archaeological domains with complex, variable targets.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Publication bias creates unrealistic expectations for ML practitioners
trigger_text: The overwhelmingly positive tone of these papers likely indicates a certain degree of 'publication bias'
Early-majority adopters may find ML difficult to implement effectively
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Connection between biased literature and adoption difficulties implies a gap between expectations and reality for new practitioners.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Resource reporting enables informed cost-benefit decisions about ML adoption
trigger_text: We also present time, expertise and resourcing requirements, a rarity in ML-for-archaeology publications
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Emphasis on rare resource reporting implies this information is necessary for informed decision-making.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Negative results have scientific value for advancing methodological understanding
trigger_text: it is important to document unsuccessful attempts to apply ML techniques
This paper offers a cautionary tale
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Framing failure as valuable contribution implies negative results advance knowledge by helping others avoid similar pitfalls.

research_designs.design_text: Hypothesis-testing design for CNN transfer learning evaluation
research_designs.verbatim_quote: We set out to detect burial mounds... using IKONOS high-resolution satellite imagery. We developed a pre-trained CNN

research_designs.design_text: Comparative design testing two training strategies
research_designs.verbatim_quote: We first used an indiscriminate collection of burial mounds... We next used only those mounds that we deemed easily discernible

research_designs.design_text: External validation design using independent field ground truth
research_designs.verbatim_quote: we applied the models to our imagery and validated results using our field data

methods.verbatim_quote: we used a pre-trained CNN, a technique known as transfer learning... ResNet-50 seemed to perform best
fieldwork covered some 85 sq km, inspected directly via pedestrian survey
we manually validated model performance... verified mound predictions using points marking ground-truthed mounds

methods.method_text: Literature review via Web of Science
methods.verbatim_quote: annual publication count... in Web of Science for 'topic' including 'archaeology'

protocols.protocol_text: Training data: 150x150m cutouts, MOUND/NOT MOUND, augmentation, 70:20:10 split
protocols.verbatim_quote: 150 x 150 m square polygons... cutouts were divided into training, validation, and test sets following a 70:20:10 ratio
deployed using TensorFlow 2 in Python... data augmentation techniques to constrain model performance

protocols.protocol_text: Field recording: GPS, height, diameter, land use, preservation
protocols.verbatim_quote: Each mound was recorded with a GPS point, height, diameter, and surface and surrounding land use

protocols.protocol_text: Validation: >0.599 probability, 150m polygons, intersect ground truth, classify TP/FP/FN
protocols.verbatim_quote: prediction records whose mound-probability exceeded 0.599... intersected these polygons with the points marking ground-truthed mounds

protocols.protocol_text: Web of Science search with manual review
protocols.verbatim_quote: in Web of Science... manually reviewed to eliminate any publications that did not in fact discuss archaeology or ML/AI
